reviewText: This is a terrfic film, but it is NOT a 2.35.1 transfer. This film was made in Cinemascope, and was a visual treat. This is a pan and scan cropped image, so in a few words - don t buy it, until it's transferred properly. Vincente Minnelli was a master of gorgeously composed images, and he was a genious with colour, but this copy looks like it was filmed through a brown paper bag. I saw this film recently in a cinema, and the image was gorgeous. Not so here. Warner Bros - this just isn't good enough for  film of this calibre.

reviewText: This did not catch me up although I think the actors did their damndest... I think the material they had to work with was a bit disjointed and didn't really convey a sturdy plot for the era.  I guess I was expecting more with Robert Mitchum and Eleanor Parker as I've seen him in "Cape Fear" and he was SCARY.  It just didn't do a lot for me considering who was cast... I've seen Eleanor Parker in a few movies on TCM and she can be bland or brilliant, but this wasn't "all that."  Sorry.
summary: Very old standards and dis-connected plot

reviewText: I love this movie!  I loved it so much, I bought the book -- believe me, the movie is better!  This is the first time I remember seeing George Peppard in anything.  He played Rafe, the illegitimate son, and for me, he was the best!  George Hamilton was good as the brooding, mixed-up Theron.  If you like steamy dramas, this is the movie for you.
summary: Life in the South ala Tennessee Williams!

reviewText: This is an excellent film: multi-faceted, psychologically thought-provoking, realistic and STILL RELEVANT as social commentary.The character Raph (pronounced 'rafe', short for 'Raphael') played by George Peppard is especially well done and provides a celloid role model for all young men:  the world would be a better place if more victims of societal injustice were able to retain their dignity and humanity in the way Raph does.  Bravo to all involved in bringing this wonderful film to the viewing public.
summary: The Character of Raph is a Role Model for All Young Men

reviewText: I first saw "Home From the Hill" in 1960 when I was a young varsity basketball player. There was a girl at Acadia whose twin sister went to another university and was down for the weekend. Their last name was Peppard. The movie was 2 and 1`/2 hrs. long and I love it as much now as I did then. Robert Mitchum, George Hamilton, Elenore Parker and a young actor who turned out to be the real hero of the movie was indeed George..  named George Peppard. They knew George was was studying acting, but didn't know he was in the movie. When they first saw him they both went crazy....it's cousin George!......It's cousin George! It turned out that he was their first cousin. It was his breakout movie& the rest is history.  I'm not going to describe the weekend. Acadia was famous at that time for it's basketball team & we lost the Canadian National title by one pt. in the third overtime. No three point shots then. I'm not going to tell you about the movie, but I always remembered the opening credits," Home is the sailor, home from the sea, and the hunter home from the hill"....Tennyson.I hope you'll indulge my "memories" but at 71 you've lost a lot of friends, including recently the American basketball starting 5 as I was, (double date) player from the I sincerely thank you for indulging the memories of a 71 year old. The other reviewers(80) will tell you all you need to know about the plot of the movie, so I don't have to. Please see it!

reviewText: Robert Mitchum is my favorite actor.  This is a perfect vehicle for this somewhat cynical star as he portrays a wealthy landowner resigned to his wife shutting him out.  There are numerous intertwined relationships.  It is a 1960 film and one can sense from this one effort that the 60's are going to be different from the 50's in terms of subjects and how they are approached.JL Penfold

reviewText: This movie was directed by Vincent Minelli and stars Robert Mitchum and Eleanor Parker and a very younfg George Hamilton and George Peppard.Mitchum plays a larger than life manwho cast a big shadow over the Texas backwoodsmen who work his land, over the beautiful embittered wife he cheats on an over his two sons-one his and one illegimate who strife for their father's respect. Epic tale of clash between the generations. Wade's sons determined to be their own men, yet in danger of repeating their father's life-crippling legacy of lust and violence.

reviewText: This movie was fantastic. Robert Mitchum stars but it is almost a supporting role. The movie surrounds unfortunate events that today may seem ordinary. Children born out of wed lock, A prominent family that only looks good on the outside looking in. A brothers love for his illegitimate brother. The illegitimate son's love for his younger half brother. Well written and directed. A young George Peppard and George Hamilton, and fantastic supporting role of Eleanor Parker. Why this movie isn't more popular I don't know.

reviewText: Guess I saw an article about Robert Mitchum in the paper the other day because I find myself with like five of his movies checked out from our library and waiting on top of the tube to be enjoyed. "Home from the HIll" was first.Anyway,it started a little slowly, but quickly developed into a very moving film where you really cared about the characters and what happened to them-rapscallion father (Mitchum), mother (later Maria's adversary in "The Sound of Music"), son Theron (Hamilton) and--ahem--bastard son Rafe (an unrecognizable but most excellent George Peppard)--all do superb jobs of acting.  The ending went an entirely different direction than I expected (an added bonus!!!)and left me satisfied and contemplative.
summary: Who knew George Hamilton could act?
